subject: Re: [junit] Re: Running Multiple Fixtures in junit.swingui.TestRunner
msgSnippet: ... Oh.  Proper usage.  From the Fixture section on JUnit Web site: http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/cookbook/cookbook.htm Tests need to run against the
messageBody:
On Thu, 6 Nov 2003, Dave Astels wrote:

> > > I've just recently started using junit and I've got a
> > > quick question. I've created a series of tests using
> > > a fixture which look (in form) like the following:
> >
> > Jargon Alert: a fixture is what you make assertions about. Usually
> > the fixture is created in setUp() and tested in your testA(), testB(),
> > etc.
>
> Ah.. but in proper usage TestCase == fixture... so I have no argument
> with his use of the word... assuming he's doing it "right" (i.e. his
> TestCase is maximally cohesive)

Oh. Proper usage. From the Fixture section on JUnit Web site:

http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/cookbook/cookbook.htm

"Tests need to run against the background of a known set of objects. This
set of objects is called a test fixture. When you are writing tests you
will often find that you spend more time writing the code to set up the
fixture than you do in actually testing values."
...
"For example, to write several test cases that want to work with different
combinations of 12 Swiss Francs, 14 Swiss Francs, and 28 US Dollars, first
create a fixture:

public class MoneyTest extends TestCase {
private Money f12CHF;
private Money f14CHF;
private Money f28USD;

protected void setUp() {
f12CHF= new Money(12, "CHF");
f14CHF= new Money(14, "CHF");
f28USD= new Money(28, "USD");
}
}

Once you have the Fixture in place, you can write as many Test Cases as
you'd like."

The next section is entitled Test Case. If you read it, you will see
that in this context a test case is an individual method that uses the
fixture.

In other words, a TestCase incorporates a fixture, but certainly the two
are not identical. You know, just as testing is an essential part of
test-driven development, but the two are not the same.

You may choose to use the term "fixture" for something else. But in the
JUnit context, it's the set of objects that get tested in the test case
methods. Typically these are instantiated and initialized in the setUp()
method.

The term is also defined in the "setUp" section of
http://jxcl.sourceforge.net/junit.html
with a skeletal example and in the glossary at
http://jxcl.sourceforge.net/glossary.html
